WORLD TRAVEL WEBSITES 

   (For release Sun., June 27 ) 
(jt) 
 c.1999 N.Y. Times News Service    

   Sifting through the many Web sites that offer tourists
information about foreign cities can be fascinating or frustrating.
How can first-time, English-speaking travelers planning a trip to
Tokyo, for instance, know if a Web site is steering them in the
right direction?

   Eight New York Times correspondents offer their views of
selected Web sites for cities they know well: Rio de Janeiro,
Tokyo, London, Paris, New Delhi, Cape Town, Vancouver and Sydney.

   RIO DE JANEIRO: The Site From Ipanema, And Lots of Carioca
Spirit

   By LARRY ROHTER

   As befits a city that ranks as one of the most beautiful and
fascinating in the world, Rio de Janeiro is the focus of numerous
Web sites in English, more than I anticipated. Many are of high
quality in terms of text and visual content, with sharp graphics
and even snatches of the music that defines Rio. Three sites in
particular stand out, each for a different reason.

   I found that the Brazilian Incentive and Tourism home page at
www.bitourism.com, for instance, contained the most detailed
information on hotels, offering small but clear photos of the
exteriors and interiors of the city's main hotels, as well as
information about their services and amenities.

   The Excite City Guide, citynet.excite.com, was useful mostly
because of its links to the Fodor's hotel and restaurant indexes
(which make judgments that I didn't always agree with).

   But probably the most entertaining site is that at
www.ipanema.com. Somehow it manages to be funny and cheeky while
also being comprehensive: there is a ``Rio Gay Guide,'' ``Rio for
Beginners'' and a section called ``Dogs From Ipanema,'' which
offers a walking tour. The site also has pictures of the city's
most famous neighborhood.

   Some other sites with fancy graphics and interesting concepts
seemed sloppy on content, however. Looking at a site devoted to
Rio's golf courses at www.activelifestyle.com/gt/riogolf.html, I
was distracted by the consistent misspelling of the city's name. If
they can't get that right, I wondered, what does that say about the
reliability of the rest of the information?

   It was much easier to forgive deficiencies in the homemade Web
sites created by Rio residents. Even though the spelling and
grammar may occasionally be wobbly, a passion for the city shines
through and there are plenty of tips about restaurants, nightclubs
and other amusements.

   In this category, I found the sites at www.riowithlove.com and
www.123-rio.com to be especially useful and imbued with Carioca
spirit.

   One last recommendation: if you're thinking of going to Rio at
Carnival time, or even if you're not, it's worth paying a visit to
the Rio de Janeiro Samba Home Page, at love-rio.com/samba. Here you
will find a thorough history of Carnival and a guide to the samba
schools that compete for honors in the parade that is the highlight
of the annual bacchanal.

   The photographs of dancers and musicians in their extravagant
but skimpy costumes were taken at this February's contest and are
stunning.

   TOKYO: An Internet Miracle: A $21 Hotel Room

   By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

   A hotel room in Tokyo for $21? It seems incredible, but the
Hotel New Koyo charges just 2,500 yen for its smallest single
rooms, including service charge and tax. In a city where a fine
melon can cost more than $100, that is an extraordinary find, and I
turned it up through a Web site called Planet Tokyo at
www.pandemic.com/tokyo.

   Information about Tokyo abounds on the Internet, but Planet
Tokyo is perhaps the best Web site for visitors. It offers a range
of information about restaurants and hotels _ the $300-a-night
variety and the $21 kind _ as well as temples and shrines and even
the Japanese language. The information is mostly timely and
accurate and ranges from the serious to the whimsical: this is the
only Web site I know of that tutors people in expressions like
``mapputatsuni hiki sakuwayo,'' which means ``I will tear you in
half.''

   Planet Tokyo has separate sections for restaurants, hotels,
sightseeing, general trip planning and travelers' tales. It does
not have a site index, but it is easy to navigate. Under
sightseeing, for example, it offers a four-paragraph introduction
and then a list of 19 possibilities, from amusement parks to the
Ueno Zoo, which is more than 100 years old. Click on any of them,
and you get the information.

   There is also a general section of ``culture notes,'' such as
how to bow and when to give gifts and take off your shoes. One of
the very few mistakes is in the language section, suggesting that
``moshi moshi'' can be used as a greeting when entering a room.
Moshi moshi is used only on the phone or when you call out to a
stranger _ for instance, a passer-by who has dropped his wallet.

   While Planet Tokyo is the best place to start, it is a bit short
on history. So turn also to Exploring Old Tokyo at
www.twics.com/eds/oldtokyo. It has information about museums,
shrines and temples, even about a historic Edo Period public
toilet.

   Still, one of the problems of these Web sites is their inability
to be helpful with directions: Tokyo is so huge that location
matters enormously. Perhaps it will take 10 minutes to get some
place, or perhaps two hours, but there is not much guidance.

   Then there is the larger question of whether these sites,
however rich in information, are any better than a guidebook. A
guidebook is easier to consult on an airplane, or to browse through
on a subway, and the fact-checking may be a bit more thorough. But
these sites are good resources for someone making a quick business
trip without much time for sightseeing.

   Moreover, many Tokyo places have their own Web sites as well
(some are linked to Planet Tokyo). When I read about Hotel New
Koyo, I was skeptical that it really had rooms for 2,500 yen. So I
telephoned, and the clerk confirmed the price and referred me to
its English language Web site: www   .tctv.ne.jp/members/new-koyo. It
popped out in a moment, with all the information I could want,
including photos.

   LONDON: So Many Choices, So Many Glitches

   By SARAH LYALL

   There are so many Web sites about London that it should be easy
to find one that satisfies basic tourist needs: clear, concise
information about where to stay, what to do and the like. But I
tried three, and was beset with frustration at every turn. They
were either too commercial, too sparse on information, or too full
of glitches to make the cybertrip worthwhile.

   The first, www.tourist.co.uk, certainly looked encouraging,
promising a comprehensive guide to the city. But something was
strange. In the hotel category, for instance, the site asked for my
desired location and price range but then listed only a fraction of
the hotels that met the criteria. When I asked for hotels in
central London that were under $70 (40 pounds) a night, I got only
seven names (none with addresses or phone numbers, or Web links,
another annoyance). When I asked for ones that cost over $210 a
night, I got only four (one, the Savoy, had a Web link).

   Likewise, the restaurant list was patchy and haphazard, and it
soon became clear that only some establishments (presumably those
that had paid a fee) had been included. All along, I was exhorted
to call different numbers _ one for a tourist information service,
and another offering help with reservations _ rather than being
given the basic information I needed.

   My next stop was www.a-london-guide.co.uk, which proclaims
itself the guide to ``virtual London.'' It started off very
promisingly, with a forecast of the day's weather in London and
some good, well-written advice about arriving in the city (such as
where the airports are). But the site appeared to have one aim: to
get you to buy its guides to London, on CD-ROM ($39.99) or video
($24.99). No thanks!

   That left the most promising of all, www.londontown.com, the
official site of the London Tourist Board. The board is usually
extremely helpful and thorough, and its Web site looked that way,
too. Not only did it offer guides to the London's popular sights,
but it also included an extensive list of millennium events and
attractions scheduled to open (or to be renovated) this year and in
the first few years of the next century. They ranged from the
Vinopolis, an all-about-wine attraction scheduled to open next
month, to a spiral-like extension of the Victoria and Albert Museum
planned for 2004.

   I was delighted by its opening graphic, inviting you to click on
to the section of a spinning globe that represents where you'll be
traveling from (when I clicked on to New York, I was told about a
special deal being offered for departures from there by British
Airways and the Forte hotel chain).

   But then it all went wrong. I tried my standard test again:
Could I use the site to find a hotel that I wanted to stay in? The
site listed types of hotels, ranging from inns to youth hostels,
and invited me to choose a neighborhood, amenities and a host of
other options. The list was clearly comprehensive. In central
London, for instance, the site promised to list 150 hotels.

   When I went further, however, trying to get a list of the actual
items, my computer began to emit a horrible grating noise and
froze. I thought I was having a bad computer day, but when I got
our office's computer expert involved, he had the same problem.
Perhaps it was the Web site that was having a bad day (colleagues
had better luck a couple of weeks later.) By this time, though, I
was thoroughly disillusioned. All I wanted was a nice,
old-fashioned guide in the shape of an actual book.

   PARIS: From the Louvre, To the Sewers

   By ALAN RIDING

   France was slow to join the cyberworld, but all the basic
information that a visitor to Paris needs can now be found on the
Web.

   Paris Tourisme, at www.paris-tourisme   .com, is a good place to
start. A click on ``Welcome'' calls up an menu in English divided
into nine chapters, among them: Museums, Hotels, City Tours,
detailed maps of Paris and its suburbs; Paris Airports and Paris
for Kids. Each chapter heading leads to a wide range of options. In
the museums listing, for instance, there is lively information on
no fewer than 42 museums.

   The Paris for Kids section includes attractions, parks and zoos,
and even suggests where to find baby sitters at night. Under the
heading Paris From A . . . to Z is a range of practical information
like where to rent bicycles, how to find philatelists and which is
the best flea market. This site offers a limited selection of
hotels and has no information on restaurants, but it has a good
search engine. The site promotes the Touringscope bus trips around
Paris in addition to walking tours.

   The French government sponsors two sites. The Paris Convention
and Visitors Bureau site, www.paris-touristoffice.com, switches
into English by clicking on a Union Jack. It offers 10 chapters,
including some not listed by Paris Tourisme. Paris night life
covers everything from cabarets and opera houses to jazz clubs and
trendy cafes (it notes, for example, that Le Flore in
St.-Germain-des-Pres is host to philosophical discussions in
English at 7 p.m. on the first Wednesday of the month). The
restaurants section even includes where to find dining spots with,
say, terraces or views, while the hotel information offers a broad
choice, from student hostels to luxury hotels (in picking a price
range, be sure to use French francs). Although this site does not
have a search function, it does offer links to other Paris Web
sites.

   The French Tourist Office, www.fgtousa.org/regional/paris.htm,
is another source of extensive information about Paris _ offering
numerous links to other sites. An example: a click on general
information leads to ``wines,'' which in turn leads to tips on
wine-tasting classes, including those that are held in English. The
site even offers pen portraits of close to 100 famous French men
and women.

   Some other useful Web sites are maintained by entities outside
of France. The (AT)Paris Traveler's Guide, at infocities.com, is
lively, though I noticed its information about museums was limited.
I enjoyed the Lonely Planet site,
lonelyplanet.com/dest/eur/par.htm, if only because it starts with
an introduction to French history and its recommended reading list
ranges from Rousseau and Voltaire to Marguerite Duras and Michel
Foucault. For the off-the-beaten-track visit, it even proposes the
Paris sewers (I have been there: they are interesting and not too
smelly).

   A site that seems particularly informative on hotels is
www.france.com/travel/hotels. It is run by the French Hotel
Reservation Center and covers just about everywhere _ Paris and
throughout the country. Hotels can be chosen by district and by
price, and there is a useful box indicating how convenient
different parts of town are for getting to museums, shopping,
businesses and the like.

   The information includes room prices as well as address,
telephone and a photograph of each hotel. The site even offers to
find hotels at the lowest possible rates.

   NEW DELHI: A Warm Welcome, But It's All Relative

   By BARRY BEARAK

   New Delhi's summer weather is ``warm,'' according to the Web
site of the government of India Ministry of Tourism,
www.tourism   inindia.com. ``Warm,'' of course, is a relative term.
Boiling water could be said to be warm. So, too, could a forest
fire, a spewing volcano and smelted iron. The summer temperature in
India's capital often hits 115, which, for me, is a bit hotter than
warm.

   Most of the government-related Web sites that include New Delhi
are short on reliable information and long on hyperbole. The
tourism ministry says the city offers ``an unceasing range of
activity, a million ways of saying, `You are welcome.'''

   Lonely Planet's Destination Delhi site,
www.lonelyplanet.com/dest/ind/del.htm, more accurately lets you
know what you're in for: ``You'll most likely notice the pollution,
the crowds, the smell, the noise and the ceaseless hassles before
you notice the city's charms.''

   Lonely Planet's site is no substitute for a thick guidebook, but
it does a good job of labeling most of the bare bones. India's
5,000-year history is rendered in four paragraphs. The more popular
sightseeing destinations rate about 100 words each and are
accompanied by photos and a small map.

   Fodor's site, www.fodors.com, contains a restaurant and hotel
guide, which Lonely Planet does not. Unlike many other listings,
Fodor is willing to go out on a limb and actually make food and
lodging recommendations. The site's authors have good taste; their
faults are mainly in what they omit rather than in what they
commend. For example, they focus on the high-end restaurants and
neglect very popular and less costly ones, like Nirula's.

   For the largest variety of links, the place to go is
www.indiaa2z.com. This is essentially a search engine that, when
you search ``Delhi,'' divides into categories like arts and
culture, business and economy, and news and media. It can take you
to some fairly arcane places, like the Amateur Astronomers
Association of Delhi. But it also contains some meat-and-potatoes
information (in India, the meat must be mutton, not beef), the best
of which is the Delhi City Guide, www.allindia.com/cities/delhi.

   While the Delhi City Guide also has a very abbreviated history
section, its listings of museums, galleries, markets and historical
sites are far more complete than most. The information (with
photos) about hotels and restaurants is quite reliable.

   CAPE TOWN: Pretty as a Picture, Though the Details Are Fuzzy

   By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

   I suspect that if I could read German better (it's slipped away
since high school, and learning to read road signs in Afrikaans has
helped only a little), I would think the best Web site about Cape
Town was one produced in Germany, www.kapstadt.de/allgem.htm. It
seems remarkably thorough. For English-speakers, I'm afraid, the
choices are a bit frustrating.

   One problem is that many South African Web sites seem to have a
fundamental weakness: they give nice write-ups to people who buy
ads. I could find several sites with beautiful pictures of the
city, beaches, botanical gardens, the Victoria and Alfred
Waterfront and the Cape of Good Hope, which Sir Francis Drake wrote
was ``the most stately thing, and the fairest cape we saw in the
whole circumference of the earth.'' I couldn't find any with the
kind of independently verified helpful list of restaurants and
hotels that a good guidebook has.

   Other than that, the prettiest and most comprehensive site was
www   .nelsonsguides.co.za, which is produced by a Cape Town company
that publishes pocket guides handed out free in hotels. Its opening
picture of Table Mountain, which dominates the city even more
imposingly than skyscrapers dominate New York, is stunning.
Browsing its pretty picture gallery brought up links to other Web
sites.

   For example, Cape Town has the largest aquarium in the Southern
Hemisphere, and there was a link to the Two Oceans Aquarium site.
Some choices were odd _ the picture of the three-hour scenic drive
around Cape Point is of a baboon by the road.

   The maps, reproduced from the pocket guide, are detailed. Its
pages of local history go well back and put Cape Town in its
context as part of South Africa's bloody past. But the
accommodation and restaurant pages are woefully skimpy _
presumably, only those that paid to be listed.

   Another site, www.doorway.co.za, can be slow to respond but has
the best-known restaurants and hotels. Its listings are free, but
limited to a few mostly saccharine words chosen by the lister.

   An excellent site for South Africa in general is the one
maintained by Lonely Planet guides which puts out what I think is
the best guide to the country. This site, www.lonelyplanet.com, has
a section on Cape Town and has links to a forum (Traveler's
Reports) where travelers _ mostly backpackers _ send their latest
advice about places to stay, things to do and dangers to avoid. It
doesn't give details about hotels and restaurants. For that, you
have to buy the book.

   VANCOUVER: Guides to Famous People And Family Fun

   By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

   Vancouver, much like Seattle, its near-neighbor to the south,
likes to boast that it is its nation's most tech-hip city. So it's
no surprise that a prospective visitor to Canada's great western
metropolis can find a ton of useful, interesting and quirky
information about the city on the World Wide Web.

   A good place to start is discovervancouver.com, a site full of
colorful images, including maps, weather charts and ``postcards''
from the country's western edge. It also includes links to the
Vancouver phone book and lots of trivia, including a list of famous
entertainers who hail from British Columbia (Michael J. Fox,
Raymond Burr and Pamela Anderson, among others).

   The site's funny American Page explains that Canada has a
one-dollar coin nicknamed the ``loonie'' because it has a loon on
one side, and a two-dollar coin that is sometimes called a
``toonie.'' And there is a helpful guide on dealing with an
all-too-common occurrence: How to Be Happy in Vancouver Even When
It Rains.

   The site maintained by Vancouver's convention and visitors
bureau, www.tourism-vancouver.com, has daily updates and excellent
links to information on outdoor activities like kayaking and
skiing.

   At the site www.4vancouver.com, part of the 4anything.com
network of community sites, a cybervisitor can find links to
restaurants, attractions, shopping centers and local newspapers and
magazines. For those who want to book all or part of the trip on
line, www.discoverbc.com has an excellent search engine with links
to hotels and tours.

   And then there are the quirkier links. A wonderful guide for
families with children, maintained by a Vancouver family that
consists of ``Mom, Dad, Nathan and Jenavieve,'' is
www.findfamilyfun.com. It has information on everything from berry
picking to watching bald eagles _ all written in a chatty way, and
the search for activities can be sorted by cost or location.

   A good place to see vivid images of Vancouver and the
surrounding area is www.beautifulbc.ca, created by a 40-year-old
magazine, Beautiful British Columbia. The Vancouver Art Gallery,
www.vanartgallery.bc.ca, has a wealth of images (not large ones,
though) from both temporary exhibits and its permanent collection.
The works of Emily Carr (1871-1945), probably the province's
best-known artist, are part of this cyberdisplay, including the
fanciful ``Zunoqua of the Cat Village'' (1931) and the colorful
``Young Pines and Sky'' (c. 1935). After that cultural tour, why
not go whale watching? For a ``virtual tour,'' I suggest the Web
site www.vancouver-whale-watch.com.

   SYDNEY: You Can Go Home Again, And to the Beaches

   By JANE PERLEZ

   As a onetime resident of Sydney who sneaks back annually during
the down-under summer, I found surfing the Web to explore my former
city as a vacation place a revelation. On Yahoo's Sydney Web site,
travel.yahoo.com/destinations (click on the Oceania heading or
search for ``Sydney''), I found solid, sometimes imaginative
information, on sightseeing, restaurants, transportation, hotels
and best of all, the beaches.

   The site opens with a refreshing essay by Mary Ann Harrell, a
writer who once lived in the city and who describes how the place
has changed. This is a fine mood-setting piece (originally printed
in National Geographic Traveler).

   A travel advisory from Knoll Travel Watch reminds would-be
visitors that Sydney is the host city for next summer's Olympic
Games: in September and October 2000, the city will be packed. But
the good news in the travel advisory is that street crime is not a
serious problem, except for late at night in King's Cross, an area
replete with strip joints and bars.

   The Where to Eat in Sydney guide on Yahoo, seemed accurate and
up to date. I clicked on my old neighborhood in Lane Cove and found
28 restaurants _ 27 more than when I lived there _ including a
Chinese takeout called Tow Yin. More seriously, the guide also
mentioned Doyle's on the Beach, a wonderful seafood place on the
harbor shore. A main course and appetizer (known as an entree in
Australia) would cost the equivalent of about $26, it was reported,
which sounds about right. At the top end of the scale, the guide
listed Rockpool, perhaps Sydney's finest seafood restaurant, where
main course and appetizer cost about $76.

   One of the weaker points of the site was the accommodations
listing. There are links to the major hotels, but some don't give
room rates. For example, the site for the Inter-Continental, a
luxury hotel built atop a colonial structure, offers a photo of its
building and panoramic harbor views, and gives the number of rooms
_ 498 _ and suites, but you have to fill out a reservation form to
get a rate. The hotel section does list less expensive choices,
including bed-and-breakfasts and corporate apartments in Sydney and
its suburbs.

   I was encouraged to see that the opera house, Sydney's principal
venue for contemporary dance, concerts and opera, is described in
all its glory. Ferry services on the harbor _ one of the city's
strong points _ were all listed, with schedules.

   Perhaps most innovative for the visitor interested in the beach
is www.realsurf.com. On the site's Northern Beaches Tour, I viewed
a photo of the waves at North Palmy, the local jargon for North
Palm Beach, one of my favorites.

   Larry's Report that day on realsurf.com said that ``Palm Beach
and the joey were the pick this morning, about a meter and glassy
waves, the peaks shifting about.'' However bizarre that sounds
(``barren joey'' is local slang for the peninsula at Palm Beach),
it is authentic Sydney beach talk, and a fair testament to the
sense of variety of city life that a Web site can give.

of glitches to make the cybertrip worthwhile.

   The first, www.tourist.co.uk, certainly looked encouraging,
promising a comprehensive guide to the city. But something was
strange. In the hotel category, for instance, the site asked for my
desired location and price range but then listed only a fraction of
the hotels that met the criteria. When I asked for hotels in
central London that were under $70 (40 pounds) a night, I got only
seven names (none with addresses or phone numbers, or Web links,
another annoyance). When I asked for ones that cost over $210 a
night, I got only four (one, the Savoy, had a Web link).

   Likewise, the restaurant list was patchy and haphazard, and it
soon became clear that only some establishments (presumably those
that had paid a fee) had been included. All along, I was exhorted
to call different numbers _ one for a tourist information service,
and another offering help with reservations _ rather than being
given the basic information I needed.

   My next stop was www.a-london-guide.co.uk, which proclaims
itself the guide to ``virtual London.'' It started off very
promisingly, with a forecast of the day's weather in London and
some good, well-written advice about arriving in the city (such as
where the airports are). But the site appeared to have one aim: to
get you to buy its guides to London, on CD-ROM ($39.99) or video
($24.99). No thanks!

   That left the most promising of all, www.londontown.com, the
official site of the London Tourist Board. The board is usually
extremely helpful and thorough, and its Web site looked that way,
too. Not only did it offer guides to the London's popular sights,
but it also included an extensive list of millennium events and
attractions scheduled to open (or to be renovated) this year and in
the first few years of the next century. They ranged from the
Vinopolis, an all-about-wine attraction scheduled to open next
month, to a spiral-like extension of the Victoria and Albert Museum
planned for 2004.

   I was delighted by its opening graphic, inviting you to click on
to the section of a spinning globe that represents where you'll be
traveling from (when I clicked on to New York, I was told about a
special deal being offered for departures from there by British
Airways and the Forte hotel chain).

   But then it all went wrong. I tried my standard test again:
Could I use the site to find a hotel that I wanted to stay in? The
site listed types of hotels, ranging from inns to youth hostels,
and invited me to choose a neighborhood, amenities and a host of
other options. The list was clearly comprehensive. In central
London, for instance, the site promised to list 150 hotels.

   When I went further, however, trying to get a list of the actual
items, my computer began to emit a horrible grating noise and
froze. I thought I was having a bad computer day, but when I got
our office's computer expert involved, he had the same problem.
Perhaps it was the Web site that was having a bad day (colleagues
had better luck a couple of weeks later.) By this time, though, I
was thoroughly disillusioned. All I wanted was a nice,
old-fashioned guide in the shape of an actual book.

   PARIS: From the Louvre, To the Sewers

   By ALAN RIDING

   France was slow to join the cyberworld, but all the basic
information that a visitor to Paris needs can now be found on the
Web.

   Paris Tourisme, at www.paris-tourisme   .com, is a good place to
start. A click on ``Welcome'' calls up an menu in English divided
into nine chapters, among them: Museums, Hotels, City Tours,
detailed maps of Paris and its suburbs; Paris Airports and Paris
for Kids. Each chapter heading leads to a wide range of options. In
the museums listing, for instance, there is lively information on
no fewer than 42 museums.

   The Paris for Kids section includes attractions, parks and zoos,
and even suggests where to find baby sitters at night. Under the
heading Paris From A . . . to Z is a range of practical information
like where to rent bicycles, how to find philatelists and which is
the best flea market. This site offers a limited selection of
hotels and has no information on restaurants, but it has a good
search engine. The site promotes the Touringscope bus trips around
Paris in addition to walking tours.

   The French government sponsors two sites. The Paris Convention
and Visitors Bureau site, www.paris-touristoffice.com, switches
into English by clicking on a Union Jack. It offers 10 chapters,
including some not listed by Paris Tourisme. Paris night life
covers everything from cabarets and opera houses to jazz clubs and
trendy cafes (it notes, for example, that Le Flore in
St.-Germain-des-Pres is host to philosophical discussions in
English at 7 p.m. on the first Wednesday of the month). The
restaurants section even includes where to find dining spots with,
say, terraces or views, while the hotel information offers a broad
choice, from student hostels to luxury hotels (in picking a price
range, be sure to use French francs). Although this site does not
have a search function, it does offer links to other Paris Web
sites.

   The French Tourist Office, www.fgtousa.org/regional/paris.htm,
is another source of extensive information about Paris _ offering
numerous links to other sites. An example: a click on general
information leads to ``wines,'' which in turn leads to tips on
wine-tasting classes, including those that are held in English. The
site even offers pen portraits of close to 100 famous French men
and women.

   Some other useful Web sites are maintained by entities outside
of France. The (AT)Paris Traveler's Guide, at infocities.com, is
lively, though I noticed its information about museums was limited.
I enjoyed the Lonely Planet site,
lonelyplanet.com/dest/eur/par.htm, if only because it starts with
an introduction to French history and its recommended reading list
ranges from Rousseau and Voltaire to Marguerite Duras and Michel
Foucault. For the off-the-beaten-track visit, it even proposes the
Paris sewers (I have been there: they are interesting and not too
smelly).

   A site that seems particularly informative on hotels is
www.france.com/travel/hotels. It is run by the French Hotel
Reservation Center and covers just about everywhere _ Paris and
throughout the country. Hotels can be chosen by district and by
price, and there is a useful box indicating how convenient
different parts of town are for getting to museums, shopping,
businesses and the like.

   The information includes room prices as well as address,
telephone and a photograph of each hotel. The site even offers to
find hotels at the lowest possible rates.

   NEW DELHI: A Warm Welcome, But It's All Relative

   By BARRY BEARAK

   New Delhi's summer weather is ``warm,'' according to the Web
site of the government of India Ministry of Tourism,
www.tourism   inindia.com. ``Warm,'' of course, is a relative term.
Boiling water could be said to be warm. So, too, could a forest
fire, a spewing volcano and smelted iron. The summer temperature in
India's capital often hits 115, which, for me, is a bit hotter than
warm.

   Most of the government-related Web sites that include New Delhi
are short on reliable information and long on hyperbole. The
tourism ministry says the city offers ``an unceasing range of
activity, a million ways of saying, `You are welcome.'''

   Lonely Planet's Destination Delhi site,
www.lonelyplanet.com/dest/ind/del.htm, more accurately lets you
know what you're in for: ``You'll most likely notice the pollution,
the crowds, the smell, the noise and the ceaseless hassles before
you notice the city's charms.''

   Lonely Planet's site is no substitute for a thick guidebook, but
it does a good job of labeling most of the bare bones. India's
5,000-year history is rendered in four paragraphs. The more popular
sightseeing destinations rate about 100 words each and are
accompanied by photos and a small map.

   Fodor's site, www.fodors.com, contains a restaurant and hotel
guide, which Lonely Planet does not. Unlike many other listings,
Fodor is willing to go out on a limb and actually make food and
lodging recommendations. The site's authors have good taste; their
faults are mainly in what they omit rather than in what they
commend. For example, they focus on the high-end restaurants and
neglect very popular and less costly ones, like Nirula's.

   For the largest variety of links, the place to go is
www.indiaa2z.com. This is essentially a search engine that, when
you search ``Delhi,'' divides into categories like arts and
culture, business and economy, and news and media. It can take you
to some fairly arcane places, like the Amateur Astronomers
Association of Delhi. But it also contains some meat-and-potatoes
information (in India, the meat must be mutton, not beef), the best
of which is the Delhi City Guide, www.allindia.com/cities/delhi.

   While the Delhi City Guide also has a very abbreviated history
section, its listings of museums, galleries, markets and historical
sites are far more complete than most. The information (with
photos) about hotels and restaurants is quite reliable.

   CAPE TOWN: Pretty as a Picture, Though the Details Are Fuzzy

   By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

   I suspect that if I could read German better (it's slipped away
since high school, and learning to read road signs in Afrikaans has
helped only a little), I would think the best Web site about Cape
Town was one produced in Germany, www.kapstadt.de/allgem.htm. It
seems remarkably thorough. For English-speakers, I'm afraid, the
choices are a bit frustrating.

   One problem is that many South African Web sites seem to have a
fundamental weakness: they give nice write-ups to people who buy
ads. I could find several sites with beautiful pictures of the
city, beaches, botanical gardens, the Victoria and Alfred
Waterfront and the Cape of Good Hope, which Sir Francis Drake wrote
was ``the most stately thing, and the fairest cape we saw in the
whole circumference of the earth.'' I couldn't find any with the
kind of independently verified helpful list of restaurants and
hotels that a good guidebook has.

   Other than that, the prettiest and most comprehensive site was
www   .nelsonsguides.co.za, which is produced by a Cape Town company
that publishes pocket guides handed out free in hotels. Its opening
picture of Table Mountain, which dominates the city even more
imposingly than skyscrapers dominate New York, is stunning.
Browsing its pretty picture gallery brought up links to other Web
sites.

   For example, Cape Town has the largest aquarium in the Southern
Hemisphere, and there was a link to the Two Oceans Aquarium site.
Some choices were odd _ the picture of the three-hour scenic drive
around Cape Point is of a baboon by the road.

   The maps, reproduced from the pocket guide, are detailed. Its
pages of local history go well back and put Cape Town in its
context as part of South Africa's bloody past. But the
accommodation and restaurant pages are woefully skimpy _
presumably, only those that paid to be listed.

   Another site, www.doorway.co.za, can be slow to respond but has
the best-known restaurants and hotels. Its listings are free, but
limited to a few mostly saccharine words chosen by the lister.

   An excellent site for South Africa in general is the one
maintained by Lonely Planet guides which puts out what I think is
the best guide to the country. This site, www.lonelyplanet.com, has
a section on Cape Town and has links to a forum (Traveler's
Reports) where travelers _ mostly backpackers _ send their latest
advice about places to stay, things to do and dangers to avoid. It
doesn't give details about hotels and restaurants. For that, you
have to buy the book.

   VANCOUVER: Guides to Famous People And Family Fun

   By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

   Vancouver, much like Seattle, its near-neighbor to the south,
likes to boast that it is its nation's most tech-hip city. So it's
no surprise that a prospective visitor to Canada's great western
metropolis can find a ton of useful, interesting and quirky
information about the city on the World Wide Web.

   A good place to start is discovervancouver.com, a site full of
colorful images, including maps, weather charts and ``postcards''
from the country's western edge. It also includes links to the
Vancouver phone book and lots of trivia, including a list of famous
entertainers who hail from British Columbia (Michael J. Fox,
Raymond Burr and Pamela Anderson, among others).

   The site's funny American Page explains that Canada has a
one-dollar coin nicknamed the ``loonie'' because it has a loon on
one side, and a two-dollar coin that is sometimes called a
``toonie.'' And there is a helpful guide on dealing with an
all-too-common occurrence: How to Be Happy in Vancouver Even When
It Rains.

   The site maintained by Vancouver's convention and visitors
bureau, www.tourism-vancouver.com, has daily updates and excellent
links to information on outdoor activities like kayaking and
skiing.

   At the site www.4vancouver.com, part of the 4anything.com
network of community sites, a cybervisitor can find links to
restaurants, attractions, shopping centers and local newspapers and
magazines. For those who want to book all or part of the trip on
line, www.discoverbc.com has an excellent search engine with links
to hotels and tours.

   And then there are the quirkier links. A wonderful guide for
families with children, maintained by a Vancouver family that
consists of ``Mom, Dad, Nathan and Jenavieve,'' is
www.findfamilyfun.com. It has information on everything from berry
picking to watching bald eagles _ all written in a chatty way, and
the search for activities can be sorted by cost or location.

   A good place to see vivid images of Vancouver and the
surrounding area is www.beautifulbc.ca, created by a 40-year-old
magazine, Beautiful British Columbia. The Vancouver Art Gallery,
www.vanartgallery.bc.ca, has a wealth of images (not large ones,
though) from both temporary exhibits and its permanent collection.
The works of Emily Carr (1871-1945), probably the province's
best-known artist, are part of this cyberdisplay, including the
fanciful ``Zunoqua of the Cat Village'' (1931) and the colorful
``Young Pines and Sky'' (c. 1935). After that cultural tour, why
not go whale watching? For a ``virtual tour,'' I suggest the Web
site www.vancouver-whale-watch.com.

   SYDNEY: You Can Go Home Again, And to the Beaches

   By JANE PERLEZ

   As a onetime resident of Sydney who sneaks back annually during
the down-under summer, I found surfing the Web to explore my former
city as a vacation place a revelation. On Yahoo's Sydney Web site,
travel.yahoo.com/destinations (click on the Oceania heading or
search for ``Sydney''), I found solid, sometimes imaginative
information, on sightseeing, restaurants, transportation, hotels
and best of all, the beaches.

   The site opens with a refreshing essay by Mary Ann Harrell, a
writer who once lived in the city and who describes how the place
has changed. This is a fine mood-setting piece (originally printed
in National Geographic Traveler).

   A travel advisory from Knoll Travel Watch reminds would-be
visitors that Sydney is the host city for next summer's Olympic
Games: in September and October 2000, the city will be packed. But
the good news in the travel advisory is that street crime is not a
serious problem, except for late at night in King's Cross, an area
replete with strip joints and bars.

   The Where to Eat in Sydney guide on Yahoo, seemed accurate and
up to date. I clicked on my old neighborhood in Lane Cove and found
28 restaurants _ 27 more than when I lived there _ including a
Chinese takeout called Tow Yin. More seriously, the guide also
mentioned Doyle's on the Beach, a wonderful seafood place on the
harbor shore. A main course and appetizer (known as an entree in
Australia) would cost the equivalent of about $26, it was reported,
which sounds about right. At the top end of the scale, the guide
listed Rockpool, perhaps Sydney's finest seafood restaurant, where
main course and appetizer cost about $76.

   One of the weaker points of the site was the accommodations
listing. There are links to the major hotels, but some don't give
room rates. For example, the site for the Inter-Continental, a
luxury hotel built atop a colonial structure, offers a photo of its
building and panoramic harbor views, and gives the number of rooms
_ 498 _ and suites, but you have to fill out a reservation form to
get a rate. The hotel section does list less expensive choices,
including bed-and-breakfasts and corporate apartments in Sydney and
its suburbs.

   I was encouraged to see that the opera house, Sydney's principal
venue for contemporary dance, concerts and opera, is described in
all its glory. Ferry services on the harbor _ one of the city's
strong points _ were all listed, with schedules.

   Perhaps most innovative for the visitor interested in the beach
is www.realsurf.com. On the site's Northern Beaches Tour, I viewed
a photo of the waves at North Palmy, the local jargon for North
Palm Beach, one of my favorites.

   Larry's Report that day on realsurf.com said that ``Palm Beach
and the joey were the pick this morning, about a meter and glassy
waves, the peaks shifting about.'' However bizarre that sounds
(``barren joey'' is local slang for the peninsula at Palm Beach),
it is authentic Sydney beach talk, and a fair testament to the
sense of variety of city life that a Web site can give.
